title: 107_s109
content: The "Dairy Farmer Viability Act" aims to address the declining farm-retail price spread for dairy products, the decrease in raw milk prices, and the significant reduction in family-sized dairy operations. This Act also establishes a commission to further investigate and address these issues. The "Dairy Farmer Viability Commission" is established with 15 members appointed by the Secretary, who cannot be federal government employees. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies do not affect its powers. The Dairy Farmer Viability Commission, established with 15 members appointed by the Secretary, operates independently and fills vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Dairy Farmer Viability Commission, established with 15 members appointed by the Secretary, conducts a study on improving dairy farming viability. It develops recommendations considering farm prices, competition, leverage, stability, and marketplace concentration. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 1 year, detailing findings, conclusions, and legislative/administrative recommendations. The Commission established by the Dairy Farmer Viability Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Additionally, the Commission has personnel matters outlined in Section 6. The Dairy Farmer Viability Commission members are compensated at a rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule, allowed travel expenses, and the Chairperson can appoint an executive director without following civil service laws. The Chairperson may fix the compensation of the executive director and other personnel without regard to certain provisions of the United States Code. The executive director and personnel of the Dairy Farmer Viability Commission are paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the equivalent of level V's pay. The annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule is prescribed under section 5316 of that title. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide necessary funding to the Commission each fiscal year by transferring funds from other accounts. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report.
